par.text: Samarium is a bluish-grey, hard and brittle metal, belonging to the lanthanide series. It becomes passive in air by forming a layer of samarium(III) oxide – S

C) samarium ignites in air. It displaces hydrogen from acids. Salts of samarium are usually yellow-coloured, but a few of them are dark brown. Samarium was discovered in 1879 by the French chemist Lecoq de Boisbaudran. The element was named after the mineral samarskite, which in turn was named in honour of W. Samarski, a mining engineer.
